text: ambassador Huntsman how concerned are
you by this spike in tension in the
relation between America and Beijing
well Beijing is certainly upped the ante
with the establishment of this air
defense identification zone but key from
here on will be whether or not the vice
president of the United States during
his trip to Beijing is able to build a
new level of dialogue encouraging Tokyo
and Beijing to talk building greater
trust and confidence in the regional
dialogue and relationship that will be
proof of whether or not we're moving in
the right direction because it's been
way too hot in the region that needs to
be lessened he doesn't seem to have been
able to do that today we have the
Chinese accusing America firmly of
taking Japan side we have Joe Biden
saying to a bunch of Chinese students
you have to be able to challenge your
government I mean these the kinds of
indications to you that perhaps things
behind the scenes are not progressing as
you might wish them this is this as
usual the the words to the students I
remember my first trip to China with
President Ronald Reagan you know he had
this kind of conversation with the
people of China George W Bush used to
have similar conversations about certain
values around religious freedoms and
liberty the war of words is to be
expected we have differences in the
region it's how you deal with those
differences so the measure of Vice
President Biden's success will be in the
days in the weeks ahead not necessarily
the hour after the meeting where we try
to get our sound bites in and they'll
try to get their points in as well it's
over the next week or two do you have a
lessening of tension do you have a war
of words that all of a sudden kind of
comes to an end do you have a process
that's put in place whereby Tokyo and
Beijing or able to engage in a new level
of dialogue which at least spells out
some rules of engagement a framework for
the air defense identification zone that
the Chinese have established that the
Japanese have how you deal with
sovereignty disputes it's not new it's
been around for a long time okay give me
give me some sense of the background
here or your take on the background here
you describe the region's
to halt at the moment you said the
Chinese have upped the ante why why now
well i would say that there are
transitional politics that probably play
into this xi jinping the new leader of
China is now finishing his first year in
office that first year is critical when
you look traditionally at Chinese
transitions into power he just concluded
the third plenum of the 18th Party
Congress he has to continue
consolidating his power base which
includes the People's Liberation Army
the Communist Party of China 80 million
members strong and groups like the
princelings the sons and daughters
grandsons and granddaughters of the
revolutionary elite while in Japan you
have a similar set of transitional
politics playing out with Shinzo Abby
who's relatively new to power although
it's a second go-around as Prime
Minister so you have the reality of
transitional politics which likely are
playing some role in all of this second
you have Beijing under new leadership in
ping creating some new bureaucratic
dynamics for example establishing a new
National Security Council which no doubt
is ruffling some feathers with the
military when they see more and more
civilian control over national security
I suspect that there was some thinking
along those lines when they established
without announcing to anybody else this
air defense identification zone okay
ambassador john huntsman thanks for
coming thank you
